description:
Coccidioides immitis RS is a dimorphic fungus that is the causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, also known as Valley Fever. It is a soil-dwelling fungus found primarily in the southwestern United States, particularly in the hot, dry regions of California, Arizona, New Mexico, and Texas.

The fungus exists in two forms: a mycelial, filamentous form in the environment and a parasitic spherical form in the host. In the environment, the fungus grows as a mold, producing spores called arthroconidia. When the spores are inhaled by a host, they transform into the parasitic spherical form, known as a spherule, which can release endospores that can further develop into new spherules, continuing the infection.

Coccidioides immitis RS is a significant public health concern, as the inhalation of its spores can lead to a range of clinical manifestations, from mild flu-like symptoms to severe, disseminated disease, especially in immunocompromised individuals. The fungus is classified as a select agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) due to its potential use as a bioterrorism agent.

Understanding the biology and epidemiology of Coccidioides immitis RS is crucial for the development of effective diagnostic, preventive, and treatment strategies against coccidioidomycosis.
